prompt: Analyze decision-making under uncertainty through the lens of heuristics and biases, comparing with prospect theory and dual-process models.

criteria.name: Core Theories
criteria.description: Explains heuristics/biases (availability, representativeness, anchoring), prospect theory, and dual-process models.

performance_descriptors.excellent: Clearly articulates value and probability weighting, loss aversion, reference dependence, and System 1/2 distinctions.

criteria.name: Evidence and Phenomena
criteria.description: Integrates empirical findings and classic effects.

performance_descriptors.excellent: Discusses framing, endowment effect, base-rate neglect, conjunction fallacy, and boundary conditions.
performance_descriptors.good: Covers several key effects with reasonable accuracy.

criteria.name: Comparative Evaluation
criteria.description: Contrasts explanatory power and limitations of frameworks.

performance_descriptors.excellent: Evaluates when each framework best applies, notes challenges from ecological rationality and expertise.

criteria.name: Applications
criteria.description: Applies insights to policy, finance, health, or UX.

performance_descriptors.excellent: Proposes concrete nudges/interventions and notes ethical considerations and debiasing evidence.

key_points: Define major heuristics and prospect theory components with examples.
Explain framing effects and loss aversion in real decisions.
Discuss dual-process implications for expertise and training.
Propose debiasing and choice architecture interventions.
Note ecological rationality critiques and when heuristics help.
